On 8/4/13 10:38 PM, system.nikhil wrote:
> My requirement is that if there are 10 links on one page, then I want that those 10 links should be crawled in ascending(or descending, random) order as they occur in the parent page.
> How can this be possible? Is it feasible to modify the UriPrecedencePolicy and other classes?
> I am new to this, so it will require a lot of time.

Fine control over the order that links within a single page are handled 
has never been a design goal of Heritrix. In its usual crawls, it's most 
common to get all links from a page, and relatively quickly, so fine 
ordering control among them is superfluous.

FOr your information, generally, the links are discovered on a page 
top-to-bottom, and there's a preference for enqueuing 'embeds' (inline 
images/scripts/etc) for fetching before navigational outlinks. There are 
a few settings on the 'frontierPreparer' processor that can also 
slightly bias things in different directions, but most people shouldn't 
need to mess with them (and none of them do your kind of reordering 
within a page).

The reorderings you describe are certainly possible with added code, but 
not very useful.

If you're set on this particular course, know that the various 
'extractors' are where Heritrix finds links in content; the 
'CandidatesProcessor' and 'CandidatesChain' are where discovered links 
are filtered or prepared for insertion into the frontier, and the way 
they're inserted controls the order they're later fetched. So those are 
the areas to learn to make the right changes.

Good luck,

- Gordon
